textBeforeTable: Historical Sketch Born on August 6, 1935, in Gary, Indiana, the son of Adam Benjamin and Margaret Marjanian, Adam Benjamin, Jr. became one of the Calumet Region's most dynamic and respected legislators. After graduating from Kemper Military School in Missouri in 1952, Mr. Benjamin served as a Marine in Korea until 1954. Upon his honorable discharge, he secured an appointment to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, earning a B.S. degree in engineering in 1958. Following three years of airborne and ranger training in the U.S. Army, Mr. Benjamin returned to Gary in 1961 and began teaching math and physics at Edison High School. Two years later, Adam Benjamin entered public service as the Gary zoning administrator; he gained further experience in local government acting as Gary Mayor A. Martin Katz's executive secretary from 1965 through 1966. Shortly after receiving a doctor of jurisprudence degree from Valparaiso University in 1966, Adam Benjamin began his sixteen year legislative career by winning election as a state representative. Four years later, he moved to the state senate, where he was named Outstanding State Senator by newsmen assigned to report on the Indiana General Assembly. As a state legislator, Mr. Benjamin developed a new code of ethics for legislators, worked on a new state medical malpractice act, and facilitated court reform for the Lake County Superior Court system. He became known as one of the most dedicated and hard working public officials in Indiana.
